qas.question: What are animals also a part of?
What did the enlargement of flower parts evolve to form?
What does a plant get out of forming fruit?
What are many mutualistic relationships, thus failing to survive competition?
What turned out to be unusually effective for plants to reproduce?
What did competition prove to be effective at doing?

plausible_answers.text: the dominant form of land plant life

qas.question: What did mutualistic relationships spread to eventually become?
How does a plant benefit from competition?
What reproductive method spread widely but made plants fragile?
What did accidentally scattering seeds help flower parts evolve to form?

context: Animals are also involved in the <a0_0>distribution of seeds<a0_0/>. <a1_0><b9_0>Fruit<b9_0/><a1_0/>, which is formed by the enlargement of flower parts, is frequently a <a2_0><b7_0>seed-dispersal<b7_0/><a2_0/> tool that attracts animals to eat or otherwise disturb it, incidentally scattering the seeds it contains (see frugivory). Although many such mutualistic relationships remain too <a3_0>fragile<a3_0/> to survive competition and to spread widely, <a4_0><b8_0>flowering<b8_0/><a4_0/> proved to be an unusually effective <b5_0>means of reproduction<b5_0/>, spreading (whatever its origin) to become <b6_0>the dominant form of land plant life<b6_0/>.
